image.altText: A drone image of Wadeye.

props.synopsis: For many years, the NT community of Wadeye has faced ongoing social unrest, fuelled by intergenerational disadvantage. Now, new plans are on the table for its future.

title.children: 'No silver bullet': Major plan to move residents out of Wadeye after years of unrest

image.altText: A man on a bike rides past a wall, with a painting of the olympic rings on it.

props.synopsis: Organisers are putting the finishing touches on a sporting and cultural opus they hope will transform Paris and unite its residents — but for some, the Olympics are an expensive extravagance and something that must be stopped.

title.children: 'Brisbane, show the world what's happening': Paris has an Olympic warning for Australia

image.altText: Birth trauma odyssey header

props.synopsis: An ABC investigation uncovers allegations of mothers undergoing birth procedures without consent or being medicated with antidepressants and feeling like they've been "spiked", despite saying "No".

title.children: 'I could have done it … if they'd not sabotaged me': Women speak about 'abuse' in the birth suite

image.altText: Two people standing near a coles basket

props.synopsis: A small Victorian milk company says supermarket giant Coles has removed its products from 65 Victorian stores in retribution for refusing to give the supermarket a bigger profit margin.

title.children: Dairy owners say their milk is vanishing from shelves after they refused Coles's profit margin demands

image.altText: An illustration shows a child with long COVID standing at the bottom of a big staircase, looking overwhelmed

props.synopsis: They're losing their formative years to this debilitating disease. But for too many children with long COVID, finding help is a frustrating and traumatic process that leaves them feeling isolated and invisible.

title.children: The myth that COVID is 'harmless' for kids has left millions of children with long COVID invisible. Here's what they want you to know

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed and a serious look on his face. The Hard Quiz has been added behind his head

props.synopsis: You're back to make up for last week's pitiful attempt? Let's see what you've got.

title.children: Hoping to end your losing streak? We'll see about that. Let's play … HARD!

image.altText: Julia Baird, who has short brown-blonde hair and is wearing a black wetsuit, looks over the ocean in morning sunlight

props.synopsis: Last weekend, whilst swimming in what looked like a protected natural rock pool, I was pulled into a dangerous rip that was dumping onto a reef. My mind cleared as I slowed down and I thought: "So this is it. This is how people drown."

title.children: I've been ocean swimming for years, I know how to spot a rip. Last weekend, I almost drowned in one

image.altText: A composite image of three author images including Tim Wintor, Rachel Cusk and Paul Murray

props.synopsis: RN's Big Weekend of Books returns! Join us as we cap off a huge weekend of all things literature with conversations with some of the biggest names in publishing.

title.children: Big Weekend of Books continues with Tim Winton, Rachel Cusk, Paul Murray and more

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Paul Murray believes lying is ok — to a point
What's Shakespeare got to do with global politics?
Here's what's coming up this morning

image.altText: A satellite google maps photo of a large house at the edge of forest

props.synopsis: Investigators say they have identified more victims of Herbert Baumeister, who died before he could ever be charged.

title.children: A suspected serial killer took his secrets to the grave. Now police comb through the 10,000 bones found on his property

image.altText: Koraly Dimitriadis leans close to her daughter. Both smiling. Koraly's boyfriend is beside them and a lake is in the background.

props.synopsis: People often think it's odd that my ex is still in our lives, despite not being my partner or my daughter's dad. Five years ago, I would have agreed with them.

title.children: We've never encountered a family like ours — but it works for us

image.altText: A man in a navy blue suit.

props.synopsis: It's been a year-and-a-half since the charges first came before the courts. Monday will be the first time he has had to appear in person.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann set to appear in Queensland court on two counts of rape

image.altText: A woman in a black shirt points while talking to the camera as a crowd of people stand behind her

props.synopsis: My time in India came to an abrupt end after I held Prime Minister Narendra Modi to account. This is my full story for the first time.

title.children: As a journalist, it's strange to become the story — but in India, I'm not alone

image.altText: Photo of a blue and yellow golden fleece service station and restaurant.

props.synopsis: There are probably a few things that come to mind when reminiscing about long road trips across Australia between the 1950s and '70s. Things like overheating cars, AM radio and the unmistakable icon of the Golden Fleece.

title.children: Whatever happened to Golden Fleece, Australia's first oil company?

image.altText: Several people in formal clothes smiling

props.synopsis: Trooping the Colour is usually all about the sovereign, but this time, King Charles III had to share the spotlight with his daughter-in-law Princess Catherine, who made her first public appearance in months.

title.children: Princess Catherine attends Trooping the Colour, making her first public appearance in months

image.altText: Ariarne Titmus and Brianna Throssel sit at the end of the pool with novelty plane tickets

props.synopsis: Australia will take a swimming squad to Paris filled with giants of the sport and with a goal of topping its Tokyo haul. For a team which has already tasted so much Olympic greatness, this will be its toughest challenge ever.

title.children: This is Australia's Paris 24 swimming team. Is it ready to conquer the world?

image.altText: cash lays on a kitchen table beside a cup of tea and a list of bills owing

props.synopsis: There are a lot of different ways to dampen inflation, according to two of Australia's most respected economists.

title.children: There are different ways to dampen inflation. But is anyone listening?

image.altText: A boat sits in the ocean with its rear covered by water against a blue sky

props.synopsis: Australia has sent specialised recovery equipment to Fiji to help with the recovery of RFNS Puamau, with Fijian authorities working to prevent any potential oil spill from the accident.

title.children: Fiji works to recover patrol boat that ran aground after being gifted by Australia

image.altText: A composite image of three photos showing a tractor harvesting, a nut and a bottle of oil

props.synopsis: Australia failed to grow jojoba in the 80s but 40 years on, the nation's largest grower is experiencing booming demand from skincare users.

title.children: With jojoba products in high demand, the beauty of this crop is more than skin deep

image.altText: Man tends to large fire in bushland

props.synopsis: Indigenous fire management methods being used in WA's Kimberley are drawing international acclaim, as rangers say they are making a big difference to the health of the tropical savanna landscapes.

title.children: In one of the world's most fire-prone regions, 'cutting edge' techniques are protecting precious habitat

image.altText: Jessica Fox celebrates winning the C1 slalom gold at the World Cup event in Kraków, Poland.

props.synopsis: Australia's Jess Fox wins her 50th World Cup gold medal after topping the podium for the second time at the ICF Canoe Slalom World Cup event in Poland.

title.children: Fox posts World Cup milestone with back-to-back golds ahead of Paris Olympics campaign

image.altText: A woman's left hand strikes lettered keys on a computer keyboard with fingers that have painted fingernails.

props.synopsis: Even if a data breach doesn't end with someone using your credit card details, that doesn't mean you're in the clear.

title.children: How do scammers use data breaches to target you?

image.altText: Keiarna in a beanie travelling in front of a a valley with moutnains and clear water

props.synopsis: The cost of living's latest victim could be the Aussie gap year dream, but experts say there are still ways to backpack overseas on the cheap.

title.children: It was once a rite of passage, but now a European summer holiday could be unattainable for young people

image.altText: two cartoon blue heelers point to a pavlova and box of edamame in their fridge. a jar of vegemite is in the foreground.

props.synopsis: After being dubbed into more than 20 languages, Bluey is helping migrant families around Australia remain connected to their language and culture.

title.children: Wanting to raise bilingual children? Here's why these mums are using Bluey

image.altText: Woman in purple shirt hugging woman in grey jumper on street

props.synopsis: Shelley and Jo are an unusual pair, but a chance meeting in a Brisbane car park changed their lives.

title.children: A chance meeting in a car park helped Shelley travel the 'long road' away from domestic violence

image.altText: An aerial view shows a lake known as Kulong Biru formed by a flooded tin mine in Indonesia.

props.synopsis: Indonesia has the highest crocodile attack rate in the world — but it's likely not for the reason you think.

title.children: Illegal tin mines linked to increase in croc attacks in Indonesia

image.altText: A man in armour with a sword sits on a horse, galloping around a field with crowds watching.

props.synopsis: The unhinged deep-dive into US renaissance fair subculture you didn't know you needed, plus four more new-to-streaming shows to watch this month.

title.children: What to watch tonight, from an unhinged renaissance fair doco to Jake Gyllenhaal's new legal thriller

image.altText: A man with a mohawk straightens the hair of another punk man.

props.synopsis: Food insecurity is rising sharply in Myanmar, prompting community volunteers to raise donations and share their own resources to help others survive.

title.children: As hunger grips Myanmar, punks lend a hand to the most vulnerable

image.altText: Prince Charles and Camilla at Broadbeach

props.synopsis: Luxury tropical island stays, quokka experiences, wine tours and opera performances are all being proposed for the king and queen's itinerary during their expected visit to Australia towards the end of the year.

title.children: Australian premiers are vying to host King Charles and Queen Camilla, but one expert says this state will be hard to pass up

image.altText: A man and a woman sit at a table looking at the camera. A number of medications sit on the table in front of them.

props.synopsis: Doctors in Greater Western Sydney say patients are avoiding trips to the GP because they can't afford to pay the gap, as new data indicates access to quality healthcare is the regions' number one concern.

title.children: Even as the cost of living rises, there's a bigger concern for people in Western Sydney

image.altText: Lamine Yamal playing for Spain against Croatia at Euro 2024.

props.synopsis: Teenager Lamine Yamal impresses in Spain's convincing 3-0 victory over Croatia in Berlin, while defending champions Italy recover from the shock of conceding the fastest goal ever scored at a European Championship to beat Albania 2-1.

title.children: Spanish 16yo makes European Championship history as three-time winners brush aside Croatia

image.altText: a tiny yellow and black coloured frog sits on the fingers of a gloved hand

props.synopsis: More than 3,400 southern corroboree frog eggs have been released into their natural habitat in the NSW Snowy Mountains in the hope of bringing the iconic species back from the brink of extinction.

title.children: Only 50 of these tiny frogs are left in the wild, but a drop of thousands of eggs in Kosciuszko National Park may change that

image.altText: Ladies in Black hero

props.synopsis: The book and then the film of Ladies in Black have been roaring successes. Now the women of the Goodes department store are back, taking on the challenges of 1960s Sydney.

title.children: Ladies in Black is back, this time in Sydney in 1961, with stars Miranda Otto and Debi Mazar at the helm
